title: Esophagitis: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Esophagitis**

_Esophagitis is a condition in which the lining of the esophagus becomes swollen, inflamed, or irritated._

**Causes**

*   Esophagitis is often caused by stomach fluid that flows back into the food pipe. The fluid contains acid, which irritates the esophageal lining.
*   An autoimmune and allergic disorder called eosinophilic esophagitis also causes this condition.

**Risk Factors**

*   Alcohol use
*   Cigarette smoking
*   Surgery or radiation to the chest (for example, treatment for lung cancer)
*   Taking certain medicines such as alendronate, doxycycline, ibandronate, risedronate, tetracycline, potassium tablets, and vitamin C, without drinking plenty of water
*   Vomiting
*   Lying down after eating a large meal
*   Obesity

**Infections**

*   People who have a weakened immune system may develop infections. Infections may lead to swelling of the food pipe.
*   Infection may be due to:
    *   Fungi or yeast (most often Candida)
    *   Viruses, such as herpes or cytomegalovirus

**Symptoms**

*   The infection or irritation may cause the food pipe to become inflamed. Sores called ulcers may form.
*   Symptoms may include:
    *   Cough
    *   Difficulty swallowing
    *   Painful swallowing
    *   Heartburn (acid reflux)
    *   Hoarseness
    *   Sore throat

**Exams and Tests**

*   Your health care provider may recommend the following tests:
    *   Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD), removing a piece of tissue from the food pipe for examination (biopsy).
    *   Upper GI series (barium swallow x-ray).
    *   pH testing. This test monitors for acid coming from the stomach into the esophagus.

**Treatment**

*   Treatment depends on the cause. Common treatment options are:
    *   Medicines that reduce stomach acid in case of reflux disease
    *   Antibiotics, antifungals, and antivirals to treat different infections
    *   Medicines and diet changes to treat eosinophilic esophagitis
    *   Medicines to coat the lining of the food pipe to treat damage related to pills

**Outlook (Prognosis)**

*   Most of the time, the disorders that cause swelling and inflammation of the food pipe, respond to treatment.

**Possible Complications**

*   If not treated, this condition may cause severe discomfort. Scarring (stricture) of the food pipe may develop. This can cause swallowing problems.
*   A condition called Barrett esophagus (BE) can develop after years of GERD. Rarely, BE may lead to cancer of the food pipe.

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

*   Contact your provider if you have:
    *   Frequent symptoms of esophagitis
    *   Difficulty swallowing
    *   Frequent vomiting
    *   Vomiting blood
    *   Acid reflux uncontrolled by medicines
    *   Unexpected weight loss

---

**Esophagitis**

Esophagitis is a condition in which the lining of the esophagus becomes swollen, inflamed, or irritated. The esophagus is the tube that leads from your mouth to the stomach. It is also called the food pipe.

**Causes**

Esophagitis is often caused by stomach fluid that flows back into the food pipe. The fluid contains acid, which irritates the esophageal lining. This problem is called gastroesophageal reflux (GERD). An autoimmune and allergic disorder called eosinophilic esophagitis also causes this condition.

The following increase your risk for esophagitis:

*   Alcohol use
*   Cigarette smoking
*   Surgery or radiation to the chest (for example, treatment for lung cancer)
*   Taking certain medicines such as alendronate, doxycycline, ibandronate, risedronate, tetracycline, potassium tablets, and vitamin C, without drinking plenty of water
*   Vomiting
*   Lying down after eating a large meal
*   Obesity

People who have a weakened immune system may develop infections. Infections may lead to swelling of the food pipe. Infection may be due to:

*   Fungi or yeast (most often Candida)
*   Viruses, such as herpes or cytomegalovirus

---

**Esophagitis**

Inflammation of the esophagus, also known as esophagitis, can be caused by various factors such as acid reflux, infections, and injuries. It is essential to recognize the symptoms of esophagitis to seek medical attention promptly.

**Symptoms of Esophagitis:**

*   Difficulty swallowing
*   Frequent vomiting
*   Vomiting blood
*   Acid reflux that cannot be controlled by medications
*   Unexpected weight loss

If you experience any of these symptoms, it is crucial to consult your healthcare provider as soon as possible.

**Alternative Names for Esophagitis:**

*   Inflammation - esophagus
*   Erosive esophagitis
*   Ulcerative esophagitis
*   Eosinophilic esophagitis

These names highlight the different forms and causes of esophagitis, emphasizing the importance of accurate diagnosis and treatment.

**Patient Instructions:**

If you have been diagnosed with esophagitis, your healthcare provider may recommend the following:

*   Anti-reflux surgery - discharge
*   Lifestyle changes to manage symptoms and prevent complications

It is essential to follow your healthcare provider's instructions carefully to ensure proper management of your condition.

**Images:**

Visual aids such as images can help illustrate the anatomy of the esophagus and stomach, making it easier to understand the relationship between these organs and the development of esophagitis.

**References:**

The following references provide additional information on esophagitis:

*   Falk GW, Katzka DA. Diseases of the esophagus. In: Goldman L, Cooney KA, eds. Goldman-Cecil Medicine. 27th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2024:chap 124.
*   Graman PS. Esophagitis. In: Bennett JE, Dolin R, Blaser MJ, eds. Mandell, Douglas, and Bennett's Principles and Practice of Infectious Diseases. 9th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2020:chap 97.
*   Richter JE, Vaezi MF. Gastroesophageal reflux disease. In: Feldman M, Friedman LS, Brandt LJ, eds. Sleisenger and Fordtran's Gastrointestinal and Liver Disease. 11th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2021:chap 46.

These references offer in-depth information on the causes, symptoms, and treatment of esophagitis, providing a comprehensive understanding of this condition.

**Review Date:**

The content of this article was last reviewed on August 12, 2024.

title: Esophagus Disorders | MedlinePlus
content:
**Esophagus Disorders**

The esophagus is the muscular tube that carries food and liquids from your mouth to the stomach. You may not be aware of your esophagus until you swallow something too large, too hot, or too cold. You may also notice it when something is wrong. You may feel pain or have trouble swallowing.

**Common Problems**

The most common problem with the esophagus is GERD (gastroesophageal reflux disease). With GERD, a muscle at the end of your esophagus does not close properly. This allows stomach contents to leak back, or reflux, into the esophagus and irritate it. Over time, GERD can cause damage to the esophagus.

Other problems include:

* Heartburn
* Cancer
* Eosinophilic esophagitis

**Diagnosis**

Doctors may use various tests to make a diagnosis. These include:

* Imaging tests
* An upper endoscopy
* A biopsy

**Treatment**

Treatment depends on the problem. Some problems get better with over-the-counter medicines or changes in diet. Others may need prescription medicines or surgery.

**Related Issues**

* Globus (International Foundation for Gastrointestinal Disorders)
* Barrett's Esophagus (National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases)
* Bile Reflux (Mayo Foundation for Medical Education and Research)
* Esophageal Spasms (Mayo Foundation for Medical Education and Research)
* Esophageal Varices (Mayo Foundation for Medical Education and Research)

**Genetics**

* Esophageal atresia/tracheoesophageal fistula: MedlinePlus Genetics (National Library of Medicine)
* Triple A syndrome: MedlinePlus Genetics (National Library of Medicine)

---

**Esophagus Disorders**

The esophagus is the muscular tube that carries food and liquids from your mouth to the stomach. You may not be aware of your esophagus until you swallow something too large, too hot, or too cold. You may also notice it when something is wrong. You may feel pain or have trouble swallowing.

**Most Common Problem: GERD**

The most common problem with the esophagus is GERD (gastroesophageal reflux disease). With GERD, a muscle at the end of your esophagus does not close properly. This allows stomach contents to leak back, or reflux, into the esophagus and irritate it. Over time, GERD can cause damage to the esophagus.

**Other Problems**

Other problems include heartburn, cancer, and eosinophilic esophagitis. Doctors may use various tests to make a diagnosis. These include imaging tests, an upper endoscopy, and a biopsy.

**Treatment**

Treatment depends on the problem. Some problems get better with over-the-counter medicines or changes in diet. Others may need prescription medicines or surgery.

**Diagnosis and Tests**

* Barium Swallow
* Esophageal pH Test
* Understanding Esophageal Manometry
* Upper GI Endoscopy
* Upper GI Series
* X-Ray Exam: Neck

**Treatments and Therapies**

* Achalasia - series
* Treatments for other esophagus disorders may include medications, lifestyle changes, or surgery.

**Related Issues**

* Globus (a feeling of something stuck in the throat)
* Other related issues may include difficulty swallowing, chest pain, or shortness of breath.

**Specifics**

* Barrett's Esophagus: a condition where the lining of the esophagus becomes damaged
* Bile Reflux: a condition where bile flows back into the esophagus
* Esophageal Spasms: muscle contractions in the esophagus that can cause pain and difficulty swallowing
* Esophageal Varices: enlarged veins in the esophagus that can bleed easily

**Genetics**

* Esophageal atresia/tracheoesophageal fistula: a rare birth defect where the esophagus is not fully formed
* Triple A syndrome: a rare genetic disorder that affects multiple organs, including the esophagus.

**Clinical Trials**

* ClinicalTrials.gov: Barrett Esophagus
* ClinicalTrials.gov: Esophageal Achalasia
* ClinicalTrials.gov: Esophageal Diseases

**Journal Articles**

* Differences in medical care satisfaction of patients with "functional" vs "organic" disorders
* Markers of Prognosis for Acute Esophageal Necrosis: A Systematic Review.
* Validation of the Japanese version of the Esophageal Hypervigilance and Anxiety Scale.

**Reference Desk**

* Your Digestive System and How It Works

**Find an Expert**

* American College of Gastroenterology
* ASGE: Find a Doctor (American Society for Gastrointestinal Endoscopy)
* Find a Gastroenterologist (American College of Gastroenterology)
* Find a SAGES Surgeon (Society of American Gastrointestinal and Endoscopic Surgeons)
* Find an ENT (American Academy of Otolaryngology--Head and Neck Surgery)

**Children**

* Esophageal Atresia and Tracheoesophageal Fistula
* Reflux in Children: MedlinePlus Health Topic
* Reflux in Infants: MedlinePlus Health Topic
* Tracheoesophageal fistula repair - series

**Patient Handouts**

* Achalasia
* Barrett esophagus
* Bleeding esophageal varices
* Diet and eating after esophagectomy
* EGD discharge
* Esophageal atresia
* Esophageal manometry

---

**Esophagus Disorders**

**Achalasia**

*   Achalasia - series
*   Definition: a rare disorder of the esophagus where the muscles in the esophagus do not function properly, causing difficulty swallowing.
*   Symptoms: difficulty swallowing, regurgitation of food, and weight loss.
*   Treatment: dilation or surgery to relieve the obstruction.

**Barrett Esophagus**

*   Definition: a condition where the lining of the esophagus changes to resemble the lining of the intestine, often as a result of chronic acid reflux.
*   Symptoms: difficulty swallowing, chest pain, and regurgitation of food.
*   Treatment: regular endoscopy screenings to detect precancerous changes.

**Bleeding Esophageal Varices**

*   Definition: bleeding from enlarged veins in the esophagus, often due to liver disease or portal hypertension.
*   Symptoms: severe upper gastrointestinal bleeding, vomiting blood, and abdominal pain.
*   Treatment: emergency endoscopy to stop the bleeding, followed by medications to reduce pressure in the varices.

**Diet and Eating After Esophagectomy**

*   Definition: dietary recommendations after esophagectomy surgery to prevent complications such as stricture or leakage.
*   Symptoms: difficulty swallowing, regurgitation of food, and pain during eating.
*   Treatment: soft foods, small meals, and avoiding spicy or acidic foods.

**EGD Discharge**

*   Definition: discharge from an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy (EGD) procedure.
*   Symptoms: mild discomfort, nausea, and vomiting.
*   Treatment: rest, hydration, and over-the-counter medications for pain and nausea.

**Esophageal Atresia**

*   Definition: a congenital anomaly where the esophagus is not properly formed, often requiring surgical correction.
*   Symptoms: difficulty swallowing, regurgitation of food, and respiratory distress in newborns.
*   Treatment: immediate surgical intervention to repair the atresia.

**Esophageal Culture**

*   Definition: a diagnostic test to identify bacterial or fungal infections in the esophagus.
*   Symptoms: difficulty swallowing, fever, and weight loss.
*   Treatment: antibiotics or antifungal medications based on culture results.

**Esophageal Manometry**

*   Definition: a diagnostic test using a tube inserted through the nose to measure muscle contractions in the esophagus during swallowing.
*   Symptoms: difficulty swallowing, regurgitation of food, and chest pain.
*   Treatment: relief of obstruction or stricture through dilation or surgery.

**Esophageal Perforation**

*   Definition: a life-threatening condition where the esophagus is punctured, often due to trauma, endoscopy, or cancer.
*   Symptoms: severe upper gastrointestinal bleeding, vomiting blood, and abdominal pain.
*   Treatment: emergency surgical intervention to repair the perforation.

**Esophageal Spasm**

*   Definition: abnormal muscle contractions in the esophagus during swallowing.
*   Symptoms: difficulty swallowing, chest pain, and regurgitation of food.
*   Treatment: relaxation techniques, antacids, or medications to reduce spasms.

**Esophageal Stricture - Benign**

*   Definition: a narrowing of the esophagus due to chronic inflammation or scarring, often as a result of acid reflux or infection.
*   Symptoms: difficulty swallowing, regurgitation of food, and weight loss.
*   Treatment: dilation or surgery to relieve the obstruction.

**Esophagitis**

*   Definition: inflammation of the esophageal lining, often due to acid reflux, infection, or injury.
*   Symptoms: difficulty swallowing, chest pain, and regurgitation of food.
*   Treatment: medications to reduce acid production, antibiotics for infections, or surgery in severe cases.

**Infectious Esophagitis**

*   Definition: an infection of the esophageal lining, often due to bacteria, viruses, or fungi.
*   Symptoms: difficulty swallowing, fever, and weight loss.
*   Treatment: antibiotics or antifungal medications based on culture results.

**Lower Esophageal Ring**

*   Definition: a benign growth at the lower end of the esophagus, often causing difficulty swallowing.
*   Symptoms: regurgitation of food, chest pain, and weight loss.
*   Treatment: dilation to relieve the obstruction.

**Mallory-Weiss Tear**

*   Definition: a tear in the lining of the esophagus, often due to vomiting or intense coughing.
*   Symptoms: difficulty swallowing, regurgitation of food, and abdominal pain.
*   Treatment: rest, hydration, and over-the-counter medications for pain and nausea.

**Swallowing Problems**

*   Definition: difficulty swallowing due to various causes such as esophageal disorders, neurological conditions, or anatomical abnormalities.
*   Symptoms: regurgitation of food, chest pain, and weight loss.
*   Treatment: depends on the underlying cause, may include medications, surgery, or lifestyle modifications.

**Tracheoesophageal Fistula and Esophageal Atresia Repair**

*   Definition: surgical repair of congenital anomalies where the esophagus is not properly formed.
*   Symptoms: difficulty swallowing, regurgitation of food, and respiratory distress in newborns.
*   Treatment: immediate surgical intervention to repair the atresia.

**Upper GI and Small Bowel Series**

*   Definition: a diagnostic imaging test using X-rays to visualize the upper gastrointestinal tract and small intestine.
*   Symptoms: abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting.
*   Treatment: depends on the underlying cause, may include medications, surgery, or lifestyle modifications.

title: Essential thrombocythemia: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Essential Thrombocythemia**

**What is Essential Thrombocythemia?**

Essential thrombocythemia (ET) is a condition where the bone marrow produces too many platelets. Platelets are particles in the blood that aid in blood clotting.

**Causes and Symptoms**

ET results from an overproduction of platelets. As these platelets do not work normally, blood clots and bleeding are common problems. Untreated, ET worsens over time.

Symptoms may include:

* Headache (most common)
* Tingling, coldness, or blueness in the hands and feet
* Feeling dizzy or lightheaded
* Vision problems
* Mini-strokes (transient ischemic attacks) or stroke

If bleeding is a problem, symptoms may include:

* Easy bruising and nosebleeds
* Bleeding from the gastrointestinal tract, respiratory system, urinary tract, or skin
* Bleeding from the gums
* Prolonged bleeding from surgical procedures or tooth removal

**Exams and Tests**

Most of the time, ET is found through blood tests done for other health problems before symptoms appear.

Other tests may include:

* Bone marrow biopsy
* Complete blood count (CBC)
* Genetic tests (to look for a change in the JAK2, CALR, or MPL gene)

**Treatment**

If you have life-threatening complications, you may have a treatment called platelet pheresis. It quickly reduces the number of platelets in the blood.

Long-term, medicines are used to decrease the platelet count to avoid complications. The most common medicines used include hydroxyurea, interferon-alpha, or anagrelide.

Aspirin at a low dose (81 to 100 mg per day) may decrease clotting episodes.

Many people do not need any treatment, but they must be followed closely by their provider.

**Outlook (Prognosis)**

Outcomes may vary. Most people can go for long periods without complications and have a normal lifespan. In a small number of people, complications from bleeding and blood clots can cause serious problems.

In rare cases, the disease can change into acute leukemia or myelofibrosis.

**Possible Complications**

Complications may include:

* Acute leukemia or myelofibrosis
* Severe bleeding (hemorrhage)
* Stroke, heart attack, or blood clots

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

Contact your provider if:

* You have unexplained bleeding that continues longer than it should.
* You notice chest pain, leg pain, confusion, weakness, numbness, or other new symptoms.

---

**Essential Thrombocythemia**

**What is it?**

Essential thrombocythemia (ET) is a condition where the bone marrow produces too many platelets. Platelets are tiny particles in the blood that help with blood clotting.

**Causes**

ET occurs when there's an overproduction of platelets. These abnormal platelets don't work properly, leading to common problems like blood clots and bleeding. If left untreated, ET worsens over time.

ET is part of a group of conditions called myeloproliferative disorders, which include:

*   Chronic myelogenous leukemia (an overproduction of white blood cells that starts in the bone marrow)
*   Polycythemia vera (bone marrow disease that leads to an abnormal increase in red blood cells)
*   Primary myelofibrosis (disorder of the bone marrow where scar tissue replaces healthy tissue)

Many people with ET have a mutation in one of three genes: JAK2, CALR, or MPL.

ET is most common in middle-aged people but can also affect younger individuals, particularly women under 40.

**Symptoms**

Possible symptoms include:

*   Headache (most common)
*   Tingling, coldness, or blueness in the hands and feet
*   Feeling dizzy or lightheaded
*   Vision problems
*   Mini-strokes (transient ischemic attacks) or stroke

If bleeding is a concern, symptoms may include:

*   Easy bruising and nosebleeds
*   Bleeding from the gastrointestinal tract, respiratory system, urinary tract, or skin
*   Bleeding from the gums
*   Prolonged bleeding from surgical procedures or tooth removal

---

**Essential Thrombocythemia**

**What is Essential Thrombocythemia?**

Essential thrombocythemia (ET) is a type of blood disorder characterized by the excessive production of platelets in the bone marrow. It is one of the myeloproliferative neoplasms, which are a group of disorders that affect the bone marrow and cause an overproduction of blood cells.

**Causes and Risk Factors**

The exact cause of ET is unknown, but it is believed to result from a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Some people may be more prone to developing ET due to their family history or certain genetic mutations.

**Symptoms**

The symptoms of ET can vary widely from person to person, but common ones include:

*   Thrombosis (blood clots)
*   Bleeding
*   Abdominal pain
*   Fatigue
*   Weight loss

**Diagnosis**

ET is typically diagnosed through a combination of physical examination, medical history, and laboratory tests. These may include:

*   Complete blood count (CBC) to check for abnormal platelet counts
*   Bone marrow biopsy to examine the bone marrow tissue
*   Genetic testing to identify specific mutations associated with ET

**Treatment**

The treatment of ET depends on the individual's symptoms, platelet count, and overall health. Some common treatments include:

*   Aspirin or other antiplatelet medications to prevent blood clots
*   Anticoagulant medications to treat existing blood clots
*   Low-dose heparin to prevent blood clot formation
*   Surgery or other interventions to remove large blood clots

**Prognosis**

The prognosis for people with ET varies widely depending on the severity of their symptoms and their response to treatment. With proper management, many people with ET can lead normal lives and enjoy a good quality of life.

**References**

Gotlib J. Polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia, and primary myelofibrosis. In: Goldman L, Schafer AI, eds. Goldman-Cecil Medicine. 26th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2020:chap 157.

Marcellino BK, Mascarenhas J, Iancu-Rubin C, Kremyanskaya M, Najfeld V, Hoffman R. Essential thrombocythemia. In: Hoffman R, Benz EJ, Silberstein LE, et al, eds. Hematology: Basic Principles and Practice. 8th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2023:chap 71.

**Related Health Topics**

*   Platelet Disorders

title: Essential tremor: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Essential Tremor**

\n\n**What is Essential Tremor?**

Essential tremor (ET) is a type of involuntary shaking movement. It has no identified cause. Involuntary means you shake without trying to do so and are not able to stop the shaking at will.

\n\n**Causes of Essential Tremor**

ET is the most common type of tremor. Everyone has some tremor at times, but the movements are usually so small that they can't be seen. ET affects both men and women. It is most common in people older than 65 years.

The exact cause of ET is unknown. Research suggests that the part of the brain that controls muscle movements does not work correctly in people with ET.

If an ET occurs in more than one member of a family, it is called a familial tremor. This type of ET is passed down through families (inherited). This suggests that genes play a role in its cause.

Familial tremor is usually a dominant trait. This means that you only need to get the gene from one parent to develop the tremor. It often starts in early middle age, but may be seen in people who are older or younger, or even in children.

\n\n**Symptoms of Essential Tremor**

The tremor is more likely to be noticed in the forearm and hands. The arms, head, eyelids, or other muscles may also be affected. The tremor rarely occurs in the legs or feet. A person with ET may have trouble holding or using small objects such as silverware or a pen.

The shaking most often involves small, rapid movements occurring 4 to 12 times a second.

Specific symptoms may include:

* Head nodding
* A shaking or quivering sound to the voice if the tremor affects the voice box
* Problems with writing, drawing, drinking from a cup, or using tools if the tremor affects the hands

The tremors may:

\n\n**Exams and Tests for Essential Tremor**

Your health care provider can make the diagnosis by performing a physical exam and asking about your medical and personal history.

Tests may be needed to check for other reasons for the tremors such as:

* Smoking and smokeless tobacco
* Overactive thyroid (hyperthyroidism)
* Suddenly stopping alcohol after drinking a lot for a long time (alcohol withdrawal)
* Too much caffeine
* Use of certain medicines
* Nervousness or anxiety

Blood tests and imaging tests (such as a CT scan of the head, brain MRI, and x-rays) are usually normal.

\n\n**Treatment of Essential Tremor**

Treatment may not be needed unless the tremors interfere with your daily activities or cause embarrassment.

HOME CARE

For tremors made worse by stress, try techniques that help you relax. For tremors of any cause, avoid caffeine and get enough sleep.

For tremors caused or made worse by a medicine, talk to your provider about stopping the medicine, reducing the dosage, or switching. Do not change or stop any medicine on your own.

Severe tremors make it harder to do daily activities. You may need help with these activities. Things that can help include:

* Buying clothes with Velcro fasteners, or using button hooks
* Cooking or eating with utensils that are weighted and have a larger handle
* Using straws to drink
* Wearing slip-on shoes and using shoehorns

MEDICINES FOR TREMOR

Medicines may help relieve symptoms. The most commonly used medicines include:

* Propranolol, a beta blocker
* Primidone, a medicine used to treat seizures

These medicines can have side effects.

Propranolol may cause fatigue, stuffy nose, or slow heartbeat, and it may make asthma worse.
Primidone may cause drowsiness, problems concentrating, nausea, and problems with walking, balance, and coordination.

Other medicines that may reduce tremors include:

* Antiseizure medicines
* Mild tranquilizers
* Blood pressure medicines called calcium-channel blockers

Botulinum toxin injections may be tried to reduce tremors.

SURGERY

In severe cases, surgery may be tried. This may include:

* Focusing high-powered x-rays on a small area of the brain (stereotactic radiosurgery)
* Implanting a stimulating device in the brain to signal the area that controls movement (deep brain stimulation)

\n\n**Outlook (Prognosis) for Essential Tremor**

An ET is not a dangerous problem. But some people find the tremors annoying and embarrassing. In some cases, it may be dramatic enough to interfere with work, writing, eating, or drinking.

Possible Complications

Sometimes, the tremors affect the vocal cords, which may lead to speech problems.

When to Contact a Medical Professional

Contact your provider if:

* You have a new tremor
* Your tremor makes it hard to perform daily activities
* You have side effects from the medicines used to treat your tremor

---

**Essential Tremor**

**What is Essential Tremor?**

Essential tremor (ET) is a type of involuntary shaking movement. It has no identified cause. Involuntary means you shake without trying to do so and are not able to stop the shaking at will.

**Causes of Essential Tremor**

*   The exact cause of ET is unknown.
*   Research suggests that the part of the brain that controls muscle movements does not work correctly in people with ET.
*   Familial tremor, a type of ET passed down through families (inherited), may be caused by genes playing a role in its cause.

**Symptoms of Essential Tremor**

*   The tremor is more likely to be noticed in the forearm and hands.
*   The arms, head, eyelids, or other muscles may also be affected.
*   The tremor rarely occurs in the legs or feet.
*   A person with ET may have trouble holding or using small objects such as silverware or a pen.

**Types of Essential Tremor**

*   Familial tremor: This type of ET is passed down through families (inherited). It often starts in early middle age, but may be seen in people who are older or younger, or even in children.

---

**Essential Tremor**

**What is Essential Tremor?**

Essential tremor (ET) is a neurological disorder characterized by involuntary movements or tremors in various parts of the body.

**Symptoms**

* May have trouble holding or using small objects such as silverware or a pen.
* The shaking most often involves small, rapid movements occurring 4 to 12 times a second.
* Specific symptoms may include:
	+ Head nodding
	+ A shaking or quivering sound to the voice if the tremor affects the voice box
	+ Problems with writing, drawing, drinking from a cup, or using tools if the tremor affects the hands

**Types of Tremors**

* Occur during movement (action-related tremor) and may be less noticeable with rest
* Come and go, but often get worse with age
* Worsen with stress, caffeine, lack of sleep, and certain medicines
* Not affect both sides of the body the same way
* Improve slightly by drinking a small amount of alcohol

**Exams and Tests**

Your health care provider can make the diagnosis by performing a physical exam and asking about your medical and personal history.

Tests may be needed to check for other reasons for the tremors such as:

* Smoking and smokeless tobacco
* Overactive thyroid (hyperthyroidism)
* Suddenly stopping alcohol after drinking a lot for a long time (alcohol withdrawal)
* Too much caffeine
* Use of certain medicines
* Nervousness or anxiety

Blood tests and imaging tests (such as a CT scan of the head, brain MRI, and x-rays) are usually normal.

**Treatment**

Treatment may not be needed unless the tremors interfere with your daily activities or cause embarrassment.

HOME CARE:

* For tremors made worse by stress, try techniques that help you relax. For tremors of any cause, avoid caffeine and get enough sleep.
* For tremors caused or made worse by a medicine, talk to your provider about stopping the medicine, reducing the dosage, or switching. Do not change or stop any medicine on your own.

Severe tremors make it harder to do daily activities. You may need help with these activities. Things that can help include:

* Buying clothes with Velcro fasteners, or using button hooks
* Cooking or eating with utensils that are weighted and have a larger handle
* Using straws to drink
* Wearing slip-on shoes and using shoehorns

MEDICINES FOR TREMOR:

Medicines may help relieve symptoms. The most commonly used medicines include:

* Propranolol, a beta blocker
* Primidone, a medicine used to treat seizures

These medicines can have side effects.

Propranolol may cause fatigue, stuffy nose, or slow heartbeat, and it may make asthma worse.
Primidone may cause drowsiness, problems concentrating, nausea, and problems with walking, balance, and coordination.

Other medicines that may reduce tremors include:

* Antiseizure medicines
* Mild tranquilizers
* Blood pressure medicines called calcium-channel blockers

Botulinum toxin injections may be tried to reduce tremors.

SURGERY:

In severe cases, surgery may be tried. This may include:

* Focusing high-powered x-rays on a small area of the brain (stereotactic radiosurgery)
* Implanting a stimulating device in the brain to signal the area that controls movement (deep brain stimulation)

---

**Essential Tremor**

An essential tremor, also known as familial tremor or benign essential tremor, is a neurological disorder characterized by involuntary movements of the body. The tremors can be quite dramatic and may interfere with daily activities such as work, writing, eating, or drinking.

**Causes and Risk Factors**

The exact cause of essential tremor is still unknown, but it is believed to be related to abnormalities in the central nervous system and peripheral nervous system. It tends to run in families, suggesting a genetic component.

**Symptoms**

The most common symptom of essential tremor is a trembling or shaking movement of the hands, arms, head, voice, or other parts of the body. The tremors can be quite pronounced and may be accompanied by other symptoms such as:

*   **Speech problems**: In some cases, the tremors can affect the vocal cords, leading to speech difficulties.
*   **Daily activity impairment**: The tremors can make it challenging to perform daily tasks.

**Diagnosis**

There is no specific test for essential tremor, and diagnosis is often based on clinical evaluation. A healthcare provider may use various diagnostic tools such as:

*   **Medical history**: To identify any underlying medical conditions that may be contributing to the tremors.
*   **Physical examination**: To assess the severity of the tremors and rule out other potential causes.

**Treatment**

The treatment for essential tremor depends on the severity of the symptoms. In mild cases, lifestyle changes such as:

*   **Alcohol consumption**: Drinking small amounts of alcoholic beverages may help alleviate the tremors.
*   **Medications**: Various medications can be used to reduce the frequency and severity of the tremors.

In more severe cases, other treatment options may include:

*   **Botulinum toxin injections**: To temporarily reduce muscle activity and alleviate symptoms.
*   **Surgery**: In rare instances, surgery may be considered to treat the underlying cause of the tremors.

**Prognosis**

Essential tremor is not a dangerous condition, but it can be quite debilitating for some individuals. With proper treatment and management, many people with essential tremor are able to lead normal lives despite their symptoms.

**Prevention**

While there is no known way to prevent essential tremor, maintaining good overall health through:

*   **Regular exercise**: Engaging in regular physical activity can help improve muscle strength and coordination.
*   **Balanced diet**: Eating a well-balanced diet rich in nutrients can help support overall health.

By understanding the causes, symptoms, diagnosis, treatment, prognosis, and prevention of essential tremor, individuals can better manage their condition and improve their quality of life.

title: Estazolam: MedlinePlus Drug Information
content:
**Estazolam**

\n\n

**Why is this medication prescribed?**
This medication is used to treat insomnia (difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep).

\n\n

**How should this medicine be used?**
Take estazolam exactly as directed by your doctor. Do not take more of it, do not take it more often, and do not take it for a longer time than your doctor has directed.

\n\n

**Other uses for this medicine**
Estazolam is also known as a benzodiazepine.

\n\n

**What special precautions should I follow?**
Tell your doctor if you have ever drunk large amounts of alcohol, if you use or have ever used street drugs, or have overused prescription medications. Do not drink alcohol or use street drugs during your treatment with estazolam.

\n\n

**What should I do if I forget a dose?**
If you miss a dose of estazolam, take it as soon as you remember. If it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue with your regular dosing schedule.

\n\n

**What side effects can this medication cause?**
Estazolam may cause dizziness, lightheadedness, extreme sleepiness, slowed or difficult breathing, or unresponsiveness. If you experience any of these symptoms, call your doctor immediately or seek emergency medical care immediately.

\n\n

**What should I know about storage and disposal of this medication?**
Store estazolam at room temperature, away from moisture and heat. Dispose of unused medicine properly.

\n\n

**In case of emergency/overdose**
If you take too much estazolam or experience any of the following symptoms: unusual movements; ringing in your ears; anxiety; memory problems; difficulty concentrating; sleep problems; seizures; shaking; muscle twitching; changes in mental health; depression; burning or prickling feeling in your hands, arms, legs or feet; seeing or hearing things that others do not see or hear; thoughts of harming or killing yourself or others; overexcitement; or losing touch with reality. Call your doctor or get emergency medical treatment.

\n\n

**What other information should I know?**
Estazolam may increase the risk of serious or life-threatening breathing problems, sedation, or coma if used along with certain medications. Tell your doctor if you are taking or plan to take certain opiate medications for cough such as codeine (in Triacin-C, in Tuzistra XR) or hydrocodone (in Anexsia, in Norco, in Zyfrel) or for pain such as codeine (in Fiorinal), fentanyl (Actiq, Duragesic, Subsys, others), hydromorphone (Dilaudid, Exalgo), meperidine (Demerol), methadone (Dolophine, Methadose), morphine (Astramorph, Duramorph PF, Kadian), oxycodone (in Oxycet, in Percocet, in Roxicet, others), and tramadol (Conzip, Ultram, in Ultracet).

---

**Estazolam: MedlinePlus Drug Information**

**Category:** drug&supplements

**Warning:** Drinking alcohol or using street drugs during your treatment with estazolam increases the risk of serious, life-threatening side effects. Also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had depression or another mental illness.

**Physical Dependence:** Estazolam may cause a physical dependence, especially if taken for several days to several weeks. Do not stop taking this medication without talking to your doctor. Stopping estazolam suddenly can worsen your condition and cause withdrawal symptoms that may last for several weeks to more than 12 months.

**Withdrawal Symptoms:** Call your doctor or get emergency medical treatment if you experience any of the following symptoms: unusual movements; ringing in your ears; anxiety; memory problems; difficulty concentrating; sleep problems; seizures; shaking; muscle twitching; changes in mental health; depression; burning or prickling feeling in your hands, arms, legs or feet; seeing or hearing things that others do not see or hear; thoughts of harming or killing yourself or others; overexcitement; or losing touch with reality.

**Why is this medication prescribed?**

Estazolam is used for the short-term treatment of insomnia (difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep). Estazolam is in a class of medications called benzodiazepines. It works by slowing activity in the brain to allow sleep.

**How should this medicine be used?**

Estazolam comes as a tablet to take by mouth. It is usually taken as needed at bedtime or after going to bed and having difficulty falling asleep. Follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain any part you do not understand. Take estazolam exactly as directed.

You will probably become very sleepy after you take estazolam and may remain sleepy for some time. Plan to go to bed right after you take estazolam and to stay in bed for a full night. Do not take estazolam if you will be unable to remain asleep for a full night after you take the medication.

Your sleep problems should improve within 7 to 10 days after you start taking estazolam. Call your doctor if your sleep problems do not improve during this time, if they worsen at any time during your treatment, or if you notice any unusual changes in your thoughts or behavior.

If your doctor has told you to take estazolam regularly, talk to your doctor before you stop taking this medication. Your doctor will probably decrease your dose gradually. If you suddenly stop taking estazolam, you may experience withdrawal symptoms such as difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep, uncontrollable shaking of a part of the body, stomach and muscle cramps, vomiting, sweating, sad mood, seeing things or hearing sounds that do not exist, and seizures.

**Other uses for this medicine**

None specified.

---

**Estazolam: MedlinePlus Drug Information**

\n\n

**Other uses for this medicine**

This medication may be prescribed for other uses. Ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information.

\n\n

**What special precautions should I follow?**

Before taking estazolam, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to estazolam; any other medications, or any of the ingredients in estazolam tablets. Ask your doctor or pharmacist for a list of the ingredients.

Some medications should not be taken with estazolam. Other medications may cause dosing changes or extra monitoring when taken with estazolam. Make sure you have discussed any medications you are currently taking or plan to take before starting estazolam with your doctor and pharmacist. Before starting, stopping, or changing any medications while taking estazolam, please get the advice of your doctor or pharmacist.

The following nonprescription products may interact with estazolam: allergy medications (diphenhydramine, loratadine, fexofenadine, chlorpheniramine or cetirizine); cimetidine (Tagamet). Be sure to let your doctor and pharmacist know that you are taking these medications before you start taking estazolam. Do not start any of these medications while taking estazolam without discussing with your healthcare provider.

Tell your doctor if you have ever thought about killing or harming yourself or planned or tried to do so and if you have or have ever had seizures, breathing problems or lung disease, or kidney or liver disease.

Tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. If you become pregnant while taking estazolam, call your doctor immediately.

Talk to your doctor about the risks and benefits of taking estazolam if you are 65 years of age or older. Older adults should not usually take estazolam because it is not as safe as other medications that can be used to treat the same condition.

If you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking estazolam.

You should know that this medication may make you drowsy during the daytime. Do not drive a car or operate machinery until you know how this medication affects you.

You should know that some people who took medications for sleep got out of bed and drove their cars, prepared and ate food, had sex, made phone calls, or were involved in other activities while partially asleep. After they woke up, these people were usually unable to remember what they had done. Call your doctor right away if you find out that you have been driving or doing anything else while you were sleeping.

\n\n

**What should I do if I forget a dose?**

You will probably be told to take estazolam as needed. If your doctor tells you to take estazolam regularly and you miss a dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. Do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one and do not take estazolam unless you are ready to go to bed and stay asleep for a full night.

\n\n

**What side effects can this medication cause?**

Estazolam may cause side effects. Tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away:

*   Hangover effect (grogginess)
*   Drowsiness
*   Dizziness
*   Weakness
*   Dry mouth
*   Constipation
*   Aggression
*   Agitation
*   Changes in behavior
*   Slowed or uncoordinated movements
*   Muscle stiffness
*   Leg pain

Some side effects can be serious. If you experience any of the following symptoms or those listed in the IMPORTANT WARNING section, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment:

*   Fever
*   Blisters
*   Rash
*   Hives
*   Swelling of the eyes, face, lips, tongue, throat, arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs
*   Difficulty breathing or swallowing

Estazolam may cause other side effects. Call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while you are taking this medication.

---

**Estazolam: MedlinePlus Drug Information**

**What are the possible side effects of Estazolam?**

*   hangover effect (grogginess)
*   drowsiness
*   dizziness
*   weakness
*   dry mouth
*   constipation
*   aggression
*   agitation
*   changes in behavior
*   slowed or uncoordinated movements
*   muscle stiffness
*   leg pain

**What should I know about storage and disposal of this medication?**

*   Keep this medication in the container it came in, tightly closed, and out of reach of children.
*   Store it at room temperature and away from excess heat and moisture (not in the bathroom).
*   Dispose of unneeded medications in a way so that pets, children, and other people cannot take them. Do not flush this medication down the toilet. Use a medicine take-back program.

**What should I do in case of emergency/overdose?**

*   In case of overdose, call the poison control helpline at 1-800-222-1222.
*   If the victim has collapsed, had a seizure, has trouble breathing, or can't be awakened, immediately call emergency services at 911.

**What other information should I know?**

*   Keep all appointments with your doctor.
*   Do not let anyone else take your medication. Estazolam is a controlled substance.
*   Keep a written list of all of the prescription and nonprescription (over-the-counter) medicines, vitamins, minerals, and dietary supplements you are taking.

**Brand Names**

*   Eurodin
*   ProSom

title: Estetrol and Drospirenone (Oral Contraceptives): MedlinePlus Drug Information
content:
**Estetrol and Drospirenone (Oral Contraceptives)**

**Why is this medication prescribed?**

Oral contraceptives (birth-control pills) containing estetrol (an estrogen) and drospirenone (a progestin) are used to prevent pregnancy. Estrogen and progestin are two female sex hormones. Combinations of estrogen and progestin work by preventing ovulation (the release of eggs from the ovaries).

Oral contraceptives are an effective method of birth control, but they do not prevent the spread of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV, the virus that causes acquired immunodeficiency syndrome [AIDS]) and other sexually transmitted diseases.

\n\n

**How should this medicine be used?**

Estetrol and drospirenone oral contraceptives come as tablets to take by mouth. Take once a day on the days specified by your doctor. Take your oral contraceptive at the same time on those days.

Take estetrol and drospirenone oral contraceptives exactly as directed. Do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed by your doctor.

Oral contraceptives come in many different brands. Different brands of oral contraceptives contain different doses and may also contain inactive tablets or ones containing iron. Oral contraceptives are taken on specific schedules. Be sure that you know which brand of oral contraceptives you are using and exactly how you should use it. Ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer's information for the patient and read it carefully.

Your doctor will tell you when you should start taking your oral contraceptive. It is usually started on the first day of your menstrual period or on the first Sunday after bleeding begins. You will probably be told to use another method of birth control during the first 7 days that you take your oral contraceptive. Talk to your doctor or pharmacist about what method is best for you. Follow these directions carefully to prevent pregnancy.

You will probably experience withdrawal bleeding similar to a menstrual period while you are taking the inactive tablets or during the time that you do not take your oral contraceptive. If you are taking the type of packet that only contains active tablets, you will not experience any scheduled bleeding, but you may experience unexpected bleeding and spotting, especially at the beginning of your treatment. Be sure to start taking your new packet on schedule even if you are still bleeding.

If you vomit or have diarrhea while you are taking estetrol and drospirenone oral contraceptive, it may not work as well. If this happens, contact your doctor about what to do. You may be told to use a back-up method for 7 days. Talk to your doctor about an appropriate backup method of birth control in case it is needed at any point during therapy.

\n\n

**What special precautions should I follow?**

Estetrol and drospirenone oral contraceptives may cause heart attacks, blood clots, and strokes. Tell your doctor if you smoke cigarettes or are over 35 years of age or if you have or have ever had blood clots in your legs, lungs, or eyes; conditions in which the blood clots easily; coronary artery disease (clogged blood vessels leading to the heart); cerebrovascular disease (clogging or weakening of the blood vessels within the brain or leading to the brain); a stroke or mini-stroke; an irregular heartbeat; heart or heart valve disease; a heart attack; or chest pain. Your doctor will probably tell you that you should not take estetrol and drospirenone oral contraceptives.

If you experience any of the following symptoms while receiving estetrol and drospirenone, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment: shortness of breath, leg pain, sudden chest pain, sudden severe headache, sudden changes in vision, weakness or numbness in an arm or leg, trouble speaking.

---

**Estetrol and Drospirenone (Oral Contraceptives)**

\n\n**How Should This Medicine Be Used?**

Estetrol and drospirenone oral contraceptives come as tablets to take by mouth. Take once a day on the days specified by your doctor. Take your oral contraceptive at the same time on those days.

Take estetrol and drospirenone oral contraceptives exactly as directed. Do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed by your doctor.

Oral contraceptives come in many different brands. Different brands of oral contraceptives contain different doses and may also contain inactive tablets or ones containing iron. Oral contraceptives are taken on specific schedules. Be sure that you know which brand of oral contraceptives you are using and exactly how you should use it. Ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer's information for the patient and read it carefully.

Your doctor will tell you when you should start taking your oral contraceptive. It is usually started on the first day of your menstrual period or on the first Sunday after bleeding begins. You will probably be told to use another method of birth control during the first 7 days that you take your oral contraceptive. Talk to your doctor or pharmacist about what method is best for you. Follow these directions carefully to prevent pregnancy.

You will probably experience withdrawal bleeding similar to a menstrual period while you are taking the inactive tablets or during the time that you do not take your oral contraceptive. If you are taking the type of packet that only contains active tablets, you will not experience any scheduled bleeding, but you may experience unexpected bleeding and spotting, especially at the beginning of your treatment. Be sure to start taking your new packet on schedule even if you are still bleeding.

If you vomit or have diarrhea while you are taking estetrol and drospirenone oral contraceptive, it may not work as well. If this happens, contact your doctor about what to do. You may be told to use a back-up method for 7 days. Talk to your doctor about an appropriate backup method of birth control in case it is needed at any point during therapy.

\n\n**Other Uses for This Medicine**

Oral contraceptives are also sometimes used to treat heavy or irregular menstruation and endometriosis (a condition in which the type of tissue that lines the uterus [womb] grows in other areas of the body and causes pain, heavy or irregular menstruation [periods], and other symptoms). Talk to your doctor about the risks of using this medication for your condition.

Oral contraceptives are also used to treat acne in certain patients. Oral contraceptives treat acne by decreasing the amounts of certain natural substances that can cause acne.

---

**Estetrol and Drospirenone (Oral Contraceptives)**

\n\n**What is this medication used for?**

Oral contraceptives are also used to treat acne in certain patients. Oral contraceptives treat acne by decreasing the amounts of certain natural substances that can cause acne.

This medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information.
Oral contraceptives are also sometimes used to treat heavy or irregular menstruation and endometriosis (a condition in which the type of tissue that lines the uterus [womb] grows in other areas of the body and causes pain, heavy or irregular menstruation [periods], and other symptoms). Talk to your doctor about the risks of using this medication for your condition.
Oral contraceptives are also used to treat acne in certain patients. Oral contraceptives treat acne by decreasing the amounts of certain natural substances that can cause acne.
This medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information.

\n\n**What special precautions should I follow?**

Before taking estetrol and drospirenone oral contraceptives,
tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this drug, any part of this drug, or any other drugs, foods or substances. Tell your doctor or pharmacist about the allergy and what symptoms you had.
you should know that some medications should not be taken with estetrol and drospirenone oral contraceptives. Make sure you have discussed any medications you are currently taking or plan to take before starting estetrol and drospirenone oral contraceptives with your doctor and pharmacist. Before starting, stopping, or changing any medications while taking estetrol and drospirenone oral contraceptives, please get the advice of your doctor or pharmacist.you should also know that some medications may decrease the effectiveness of oral contraceptives (birth control pills). You will need to use another method of contraception to prevent pregnancy while taking these drugs. Talk to your doctor about other ways to prevent pregnancy while you are taking this medication.
the following nonprescription or herbal product may interact with ethinyl estradiol and drospirenone oral contraceptives: St. John's wort. Be sure to let your doctor and pharmacist know that you are taking this medication before you start taking estetrol and drospirenone oral contraceptives. Do not start this medication while taking estetrol and drospirenone oral contraceptives without discussing with your healthcare provider.
tell your doctor if you have or have ever had problems with your adrenal glands (glands near your kidneys that produce hormones), diabetes that has affected your circulation; migraines or headaches that come along with other symptoms such as vision changes, weakness, and dizziness; high blood pressure that medication cannot control; unexplained vaginal bleeding; breast cancer; liver cancer, liver tumors, or other types of liver disease; or kidney disease. Your doctor will probably tell you that you should not take estetrol and drospirenone oral contraceptives.
tell your doctor if you are overweight, and if you have or have ever had high blood cholesterol or fats; diabetes; depression; gallbladder disease; swelling in a part of your body.
tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding.If you miss periods while you are taking estetrol and drospirenone oral contraceptives, you may be pregnant. Ask your doctor what you should do if you miss a period. Call your doctor and have a pregnancy test if you experience symptoms of pregnancy such as nausea, vomiting, and breast tenderness, or if you suspect you may be pregnant.
if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking estetrol and drospirenone oral contraceptives.
you should know that oral contraceptives may cause dark skin patches, especially on the face. If you have experienced changes in your skin color during pregnancy or while you were taking oral contraceptives in the past, you should avoid exposure to real or artificial sunlight while you are taking oral contraceptives. Wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen.
tell your doctor and pharmacist if you wear contact lenses. If you notice changes in vision or ability to wear your lenses while taking oral contraceptives, see an eye doctor.

\n\n**What special dietary instructions should I follow?**

*   None

---

**Estetrol and Drospirenone (Oral Contraceptives)**

**Important Information**

If you wear contact lenses, be aware that oral contraceptives may cause changes in vision or affect your ability to wear them. Consult an eye doctor if you notice any issues.

**Dietary Instructions**

Continue your normal diet unless your doctor advises otherwise.

**Missing a Dose**

If you miss doses of your oral contraceptive, you may not be protected from pregnancy. You may need to use a backup method of birth control for 7 days or until the end of the cycle. Read the manufacturer's instructions carefully and consult your doctor or pharmacist if you have any questions.

**Side Effects**

Estetrol and drospirenone oral contraceptives may cause side effects, including:

* Headache
* Nausea, vomiting
* Weight gain
* Spotting or irregular bleeding between periods
* Swelling, redness, irritation, burning, or itching of the vagina
* Breast tenderness or enlargement
* Swelling of the hands, arms, feet, and legs
* Difficulty in sleeping, weakness, lack of energy, fatigue, or change in mood

Some side effects can be serious. If you experience:

* Yellowing of skin or eyes
* Pain or tenderness of your abdomen
* A lump in your breast
* Unusual bleeding, including menstrual bleeding that is unusually heavy or lasts for longer than 7 days in a row

Stop taking estetrol and drospirenone oral contraceptives and consult your doctor immediately.

**Liver Tumors**

Oral contraceptives may increase the chance of developing liver tumors. These tumors are not cancerous but can cause serious bleeding inside the body.

**Breast or Liver Cancer**

Oral contraceptives may also increase the risk of breast or liver cancer. Discuss the risks with your doctor.

**Storage and Disposal**

Keep this medication in its original container, tightly closed, and out of reach of children. Store it at room temperature, away from excess heat and moisture. Dispose of unneeded medications through a medicine take-back program or by consulting your pharmacist about safe disposal methods.

---

**In Case of Emergency/Overdose**

If you or someone you know has taken too much estetrol and drospirenone oral contraceptives, call the poison control helpline at 1-800-222-1222. Information is also available online at https://www.poisonhelp.org/help. If the victim has collapsed, had a seizure, has trouble breathing, or can't be awakened, immediately call emergency services at 911.

**Symptoms of Overdose**

* Nausea
* Vaginal bleeding

**What to Do in Case of Emergency/Overdose**

Call the poison control helpline at 1-800-222-1222. If the victim has collapsed, had a seizure, has trouble breathing, or can't be awakened, immediately call emergency services at 911.

**Important Information for Users**

* Keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory.
* Have a complete physical examination every year, including blood pressure measurements, breast and pelvic exams, and a Pap test.
* Follow your doctor's directions for examining your breasts; report any lumps immediately.
* Before having any laboratory test, tell your doctor and the laboratory personnel that you are taking estetrol and drospirenone oral contraceptives.
* Do not let anyone else take your medication. Ask your pharmacist any questions you have about refilling your prescription.
* Keep a written list of all of the prescription and nonprescription (over-the-counter) medicines vitamins, minerals, and dietary supplements you are taking. Bring this list with you each time you visit a doctor or if you are admitted to the hospital.

**Disposing of Unused Medication**

Dispose of unneeded medications in a way so that pets, children, and other people cannot take them. Do not flush this medication down the toilet. Use a medicine take-back program. Talk to your pharmacist about take-back programs in your community. Visit the FDA's Safe Disposal of Medicines website (https://goo.gl/c4Rm4p) for more information.

**Storage Instructions**

Keep all medication out of sight and reach of children as many containers are not child resistant. Always lock safety caps. Place the medication in a safe location – one that is up and away and out of their sight and reach. Store it at room temperature and away from excess heat and moisture (not in the bathroom).

title: Estimated average glucose (eAG): MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Estimated Average Glucose (eAG)**

Estimated average glucose (eAG) is an estimated average of your blood sugar (glucose) levels over a period of 2 to 3 months. It is based on your A1C (also called hemoglobin A1C or HBA1C) blood test results.

**Knowing Your eAG Helps You Know Your Blood Sugar Levels Over Time**

It shows how well you are controlling your diabetes.

*Glycated Hemoglobin or A1C: A Blood Test That Shows the Average Level of Blood Sugar*

A1C is reported as a percent. eAG is reported in mg/dL (mmol/L). This is the same measurement used in home blood sugar meters.

*eAG Makes It Easier for People to Understand Their A1C Values Relative to Their Home Blood Sugar Readings*

eAG is calculated directly from your A1C results. Health care providers now use eAG to talk with their patients about A1C results.

**Knowing Your eAg Can Help You:**

* Understand the value of tracking your blood glucose levels over time
* Relate to your self-test blood glucose readings
* Better manage diabetes by seeing how your lifestyle and medicine choices affect blood sugar

You and your provider can see how well your diabetes care plan is working by looking at your eAG readings.

**Understanding Your eAG Readings**

The normal value for eAG is between 70 mg/dl and 126 mg/dl (A1C: 4% to 6%). A person with diabetes should aim for an eAG less than 154 mg/dl (A1C < 7%) to lower the risk for diabetes complications.

**Important Notes**

* The results of an eAG test may not match your average of day-to-day blood sugar tests you have been taking at home on your glucose meter.
* Your provider should never tell you what your blood sugar values are solely based on the eAG because the range of average blood glucose for any individual person is very broad for each A1C level. The value is only an estimate.
* There are many medical conditions and medicines that change the relationship between A1C and eAG. Do not use eAG to evaluate your diabetes control if you:
	+ Have conditions such as kidney disease, sickle cell disease, anemia, or thalassemia
	+ Are taking certain medicines, such as dapsone, erythropoietin, or iron

---

**Estimated Average Glucose (eAG)**

The value of tracking your blood glucose levels over time is that it helps you understand how well your diabetes care plan is working. By looking at your eAG readings, you and your provider can see how your lifestyle and medicine choices are affecting your blood sugar.

**Understanding Your eAG Readings**

*   The normal value for eAG is between 70 mg/dl and 126 mg/dl (A1C: 4% to 6%). A person with diabetes should aim for an eAG less than 154 mg/dl (A1C < 7%) to lower the risk for diabetes complications.
*   The results of an eAG test may not match your average of day-to-day blood sugar tests you have been taking at home on your glucose meter. This is because you are likely to check your sugar levels before meals or when your blood sugar levels are low. But it does not show your blood sugar at other times of the day.
*   Your provider should never tell you what your blood sugar values are solely based on the eAG because the range of average blood glucose for any individual person is very broad for each A1C level. The value is only an estimate.

**When Not to Use eAG**

Do not use eAG to evaluate your diabetes control if you:

*   Have conditions such as kidney disease, sickle cell disease, anemia, or thalassemia
*   Are taking certain medicines, such as dapsone, erythropoietin, or iron

title: Estradiol Topical: MedlinePlus Drug Information
content:
**Estradiol Topical**

\n\n

**Why is this medication prescribed?**

Topical estradiol is used to treat symptoms of menopause, such as vaginal dryness and itching.

\n\n

**How should this medicine be used?**

Apply topical estradiol exactly as directed by your doctor. Use the lowest dose that controls your symptoms and only use it as long as needed.

\n\n

**Other uses for this medicine**

Topical estradiol is also used to treat breast cancer, but its effectiveness in treating this condition has not been proven.

\n\n

**What special precautions should I follow?**

Tell your doctor if you have or have ever had cancer, abnormal or unusual vaginal bleeding, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, diabetes, heart disease, lupus, breast lumps, or an abnormal mammogram. Also tell your doctor if you smoke or use tobacco.

\n\n

**What special dietary instructions should I follow?**

None specified.

\n\n

**What should I do if I forget a dose?**

If you forget to apply topical estradiol, apply it as soon as you remember.

\n\n

**What side effects can this medication cause?**

Topical estradiol may cause breast tenderness or enlargement, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and vaginal bleeding.

\n\n

**What should I know about storage and disposal of this medication?**

Store topical estradiol at room temperature away from moisture and heat. Dispose of unused medication properly.

\n\n

**In case of emergency/overdose**

If you experience any symptoms such as sudden severe headache, vomiting, speech problems, dizziness, or crushing chest pain while using topical estradiol, call your doctor immediately.

\n\n

**What other information should I know?**

Use the lowest dose of topical estradiol that controls your symptoms and only use it as long as needed. Talk to your doctor every 3-6 months to decide if you should use a lower dose or stop using the medication.

---

**Estradiol Topical: MedlinePlus Drug Information**

**Category:** drug&supplements

**Using Estradiol Topical: Important Safety Information**

You should only use estradiol topical as long as needed and talk to your doctor every 3-6 months to decide if you should use a lower dose or stop using the medication.

**Monitoring Your Health**

*   Examine your breasts every month.
*   Have a mammogram and breast exam performed by a doctor every year to help detect breast cancer as early as possible.
*   Tell your doctor about any changes in your breasts, such as lumps or discharge from nipples.

**Surgery or Bedrest**

If you are having surgery or will be on bedrest, tell your doctor. They may advise you to stop using estradiol topical 4-6 weeks before the surgery or bedrest to decrease the risk of developing blood clots.

**Risks and Benefits**

Talk to your doctor regularly about the risks and benefits of using estradiol topical. The longer you use estradiol, the greater the risk that you will develop endometrial cancer.

**Symptoms to Watch For**

Call your doctor immediately if you experience any of the following symptoms while using estradiol topical:

*   Sudden, severe headache
*   Sudden, severe vomiting
*   Speech problems
*   Dizziness or faintness
*   Sudden complete or partial loss of vision
*   Double vision
*   Weakness or numbness of an arm or a leg
*   Crushing chest pain or chest heaviness
*   Coughing up blood
*   Sudden shortness of breath
*   Breast lumps or other breast changes
*   Discharge from nipples
*   Difficulty thinking clearly, remembering, or learning new things
*   Pain, tenderness, or redness in one leg

**Decreasing the Risk of Serious Health Problems**

To decrease the risk that you will develop a serious health problem while using estradiol topical:

*   Do not use estradiol topical alone or with a progestin to prevent heart disease, heart attacks, or strokes.
*   Use the lowest dose of estradiol topical that controls your symptoms and only use it as long as needed.

**Why is this medication prescribed?**

Estradiol topical gel and spray are used to treat and prevent hot flushes (hot flashes; sudden strong feelings of heat and sweating) in women who are experiencing menopause. Estradiol topical gel is also used to treat vaginal dryness, itching, and burning in women who are experiencing menopause.

**How should this medicine be used?**

Topical estradiol comes as a gel in single dose packets and in a pump that dispenses measured amounts of the medication to apply to the skin once a day. Topical estradiol also comes as a spray to apply to the skin as 1 to 3 sprays once a day in the morning. Estradiol gel may be applied at any time of day, but should be applied at around the same time of day every day.

---

**Using Estradiol Topical**

\n\n

*   **Important:** Ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain any part of the instructions you do not understand.
*   **Dosage:** Use topical estradiol exactly as directed. Do not use more or less of it, or use it more often than prescribed by your doctor.

**Applying Estradiol Topical**

\n\n

*   **Manufacturer's Instructions:** Read the manufacturer's instructions for use that came with your topical estradiol product carefully.
*   **Application Areas:**
    *   Estradiol gel in a pump: apply to one arm, from the wrist to the shoulder
    *   Estradiol gel in single dose packets: apply to one thigh, on the front of the thigh
    *   Estradiol spray: apply 1 to 3 sprays once a day in the morning (check product label for specific instructions)
*   **Do Not Apply:** To your breasts or genital area.
*   **Skin Preparation:** Ensure the skin where you will apply topical estradiol is clean and completely dry, and not red, irritated, or broken.

**Additional Precautions**

\n\n

*   **Bathing/Showering:** Apply topical estradiol after drying your skin completely. Check manufacturer's patient information for specific guidelines.
*   **Fire Risk:** Estradiol gel and spray may catch fire. Avoid smoking or being near a fire or open flame until the medication dries.
*   **Eye Safety:** Be careful not to get topical estradiol in your eyes. If you do, wash them with warm water right away and consult a doctor if irritation occurs.

**Guidelines for Application**

\n\n

*   **Self-Application:** Apply topical estradiol yourself. If someone else applies it, they should wear disposable gloves and wash their hands thoroughly after removing the gloves.
*   **Combination with Other Skin Preparations:** Discuss applying other skin preparations, including sunscreen, with your doctor.

**Continued Use**

\n\n

*   **Symptom Control:** Estradiol topical may control your symptoms but will not cure your condition. Continue to use estradiol topical even if you feel well.
*   **Stopping Treatment:** Do not stop using estradiol topical without consulting your doctor. Stopping treatment may cause your symptoms to return.

---

**Estradiol Topical: MedlinePlus Drug Information (Part 4/7)**

\n\n**How to Apply Estradiol Gel or Spray**

Topical estradiol comes as a gel in single dose packets and in a pump that dispenses measured amounts of the medication to apply to the skin once a day. Topical estradiol also comes as a spray to apply to the skin as 1 to 3 sprays once a day in the morning.

\n\n* **Estradiol Gel**: Apply it in a thin layer to one arm, from the wrist to the shoulder.
* **Estradiol Gel in Single Dose Packets**: Apply it in a thin layer to one thigh, on the front of the thigh.
* **Estradiol Spray**: Apply it to the inner arm.

\n\n**Important Application Instructions**

Do not apply estradiol gel or spray to your breasts or your genital area. Be sure that the skin where you will apply topical estradiol is clean and completely dry, and is not red, irritated, or broken.

\n\n**Additional Precautions**

If you take a bath or a shower, apply topical estradiol after you have dried your skin completely. Read the manufacturer's patient information about your topical estradiol product for information about when you can wash, shower, bathe, or swim after you apply the medication.

Estradiol gel and spray may catch fire. When you apply topical estradiol, do not smoke or go near a fire or open flame until the medication dries.

\n\n**Important Safety Information**

Topical estradiol is only for use on the skin. Be careful not to get topical estradiol in your eyes. If you do get topical estradiol in your eyes, wash them with plenty of warm water right away. Call a doctor if your eyes become irritated.

You should apply topical estradiol yourself. If someone else applies the medication to your skin, they should wear disposable gloves and wash their hands well with soap and water after removing the gloves.

Talk to you doctor about applying other skin preparations, including sunscreen, to skin where topical estradiol gel or spray is applied.

\n\n**What Special Precautions Should I Follow?**

Before using topical estradiol:

* Tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to estradiol gel or spray, any other estrogen products, any other medications, or any of the ingredients in estradiol gel or spray.
* Tell your doctor and pharmacist what prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, and nutritional supplements, you are taking or plan to take.
* The following nonprescription or herbal products may interact with topical estradiol: St. John's wort.

\n\n**Other Uses for This Medicine**

This medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information.

---

**Estradiol Topical: MedlinePlus Drug Information (Part 5/7)**

\n\n**Interactions**

*   Be sure to let your doctor and pharmacist know that you are taking herbal products, such as St. John's wort, before you start using topical estradiol.
*   Do not start any of these medications while using topical estradiol without discussing with your healthcare provider.

\n\n**Precautions**

*   Tell your doctor if you have or have ever had:
    *   Asthma
    *   Seizures
    *   Migraine headaches
    *   A bleeding disorder
    *   Endometriosis (a condition in which the type of tissue that lines the uterus [womb] grows in other areas of the body)
    *   Uterine fibroids (growths in the uterus that are not cancer)
    *   Yellowing of the skin or eyes, especially during pregnancy or while you were using an estrogen product
    *   Very high or very low levels of calcium in your blood
    *   Hypoparathyroidism (condition in which the body does not produce enough parathyroid hormone [PTH; a natural substance needed to control the amount of calcium in the blood])
    *   Porphyria (condition in which abnormal substances build up in the blood and cause problems with the skin or nervous system)
    *   Hereditary angioedema (inherited condition that causes episodes of swelling in the hands, feet, face, airway, or intestines)
    *   Gallbladder, thyroid, liver, pancreas, or kidney problems
*   Tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. If you become pregnant while using topical estradiol, call your doctor.

\n\n**Special Precautions**

*   Topical estradiol may harm other people or pets who touch the medication that is on your skin or in the container.
*   Do not let anyone else touch the skin where you applied topical estradiol for at least one hour after you apply the medication.
*   Cover the area where you applied the medication with clothing to prevent others from coming into direct contact with the area.

\n\n**Special Dietary Instructions**

*   Talk to your doctor about eating grapefruit and drinking grapefruit juice while taking this medicine.

---

**Estradiol Topical: MedlinePlus Drug Information**

**Side Effects**

Topical estradiol may cause other side effects. Call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

If you experience a serious side effect, you or your doctor may send a report to the Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) MedWatch Adverse Event Reporting program online or by phone.

**Increased Risk of Cancer and Gallbladder Disease**

Topical estradiol may increase your risk of developing cancer of the ovaries and gallbladder disease that may need to be treated with surgery. Talk to your doctor about the risks of using this medication.

**Storage and Disposal**

Keep this medication in the container it came in, tightly closed, and out of reach of children. Store it at room temperature and away from excess heat and moisture (not in the bathroom). Do not freeze topical estradiol. Keep estradiol gel away from open flame. Dispose of your estradiol gel pump after you have used 64 doses even if it is not completely empty.

Dispose of unneeded medications in a way so that pets, children, and other people cannot take them. Do not flush this medication down the toilet. Use a medicine take-back program. Talk to your pharmacist about take-back programs in your community. Visit the FDA's Safe Disposal of Medicines website for more information.

It is important to keep all medication out of sight and reach of children as many containers are not child-resistant and young children can open them easily. To protect young children from poisoning, always lock safety caps and immediately place the medication in a safe location – one that is up and away and out of their sight and reach.

**In Case of Emergency/Overdose**

In case of overdose, call the poison control helpline at 1-800-222-1222. Information is also available online at https://www.poisonhelp.org/help. If the victim has collapsed, had a seizure, has trouble breathing, or can't be awakened, immediately call emergency services at 911.

Symptoms of overdose may include:

* nausea
* vomiting
* breast tenderness or pain
* stomach pain
* drowsiness and fatigue
* vaginal bleeding

**Other Information**

Keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. Your doctor may order certain lab tests to check your body's response to topical estradiol.

Before having any laboratory test, tell your doctor and the laboratory personnel that you are using topical estradiol.

Do not let anyone else use your medication. Ask your pharmacist any questions you have about refilling your prescription.

Keep a written list of all of the prescription and nonprescription (over-the-counter) medicines, vitamins, minerals, and dietary supplements you are taking. Bring this list with you each time you visit a doctor or if you are admitted to the hospital. You should carry the list with you in case of emergencies.

---
