title: Ethinyl Estradiol and Norethindrone (Oral Contraceptives): MedlinePlus Drug Information
content:
**Ethinyl Estradiol and Norethindrone (Oral Contraceptives)**

**Why is this medication prescribed?**

Oral contraceptives containing ethinyl estradiol (an estrogen) and norethindrone (a progestin) are used to prevent pregnancy. Estrogen and progestin work mainly by preventing ovulation (the release of eggs from the ovaries). Oral contraceptives are an effective method of birth control, but they do not prevent the spread of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV, the virus that causes acquired immunodeficiency syndrome [AIDS]) and other sexually transmitted diseases.

**How should this medicine be used?**

Ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone oral contraceptives come in tablets, chewable tablets, oral disintegrating tablets, or capsules to take by mouth. Take once a day on the days specified by your doctor. Take your oral contraceptive at the same time on those days.

Take ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone oral contraceptives exactly as directed. Do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed by your doctor.

* Chew the chewable tablets and swallow without water.
* Place oral disintegrating tablets on the tongue and allow to disintegrate. Follow with 8 oz (240 mL) of water.

Oral contraceptives come in many different brands. Different brands contain different doses and may also contain inactive tablets or ones containing iron. Oral contraceptives are taken on specific schedules. Be sure that you know which brand of oral contraceptives you are using and exactly how you should use it. Ask your doctor or pharmacist for a copy of the manufacturer's information for the patient and read it carefully.

Your doctor will tell you when to start taking your oral contraceptive. It is usually started on the first day of your menstrual period or on the first Sunday after bleeding begins. You will probably be told to use another method of birth control during the first 7 days that you take your oral contraceptive. Talk to your doctor or pharmacist about what method is best for you.

You may experience withdrawal bleeding similar to a menstrual period while taking the inactive tablets or during the time that you do not take your oral contraceptive. If you are taking the type of packet that only contains active tablets, you will not experience any scheduled bleeding, but you may experience unexpected bleeding and spotting, especially at the beginning of your treatment.

If you vomit or have diarrhea while taking ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone oral contraceptive, it may not work as well. If this happens, contact your doctor about what to do. You may be told to use a back-up method for 7 days. Talk to your doctor about an appropriate backup method of birth control in case it is needed at any point during therapy.

**What special precautions should I follow?**

Tell your doctor if you smoke or are over 35 years of age or if you have or have ever had blood clots in your legs, lungs, or eyes; conditions in which the blood clots easily; coronary artery disease (clogged blood vessels leading to the heart); cerebrovascular disease (clogging or weakening of the blood vessels within the brain or leading to the brain); a stroke or mini-stroke; an irregular heartbeat; heart or heart valve disease; a heart attack; or chest pain. Your doctor will probably tell you that you should not take ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone oral contraceptives.

**What side effects can this medication cause?**

If you experience any of the following symptoms while receiving ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment:

* Shortness of breath
* Leg pain
* Sudden chest pain
* Sudden severe headache
* Sudden changes in vision
* Weakness or numbness in an arm or leg
* Trouble speaking

**What should I know about storage and disposal of this medication?**

Store ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone oral contraceptives at room temperature, away from moisture and heat. Do not store in the bathroom.

Dispose of unused ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone oral contraceptives safely. Do not flush them down the toilet or drain.

**What other information should I know?**

Ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone oral contraceptives may cause heart attacks, blood clots, and strokes. Tell your doctor if you smoke or are over 35 years of age or if you have or have ever had blood clots in your legs, lungs, or eyes; conditions in which the blood clots easily; coronary artery disease (clogged blood vessels leading to the heart); cerebrovascular disease (clogging or weakening of the blood vessels within the brain or leading to the brain); a stroke or mini-stroke; an irregular heartbeat; heart or heart valve disease; a heart attack; or chest pain. Your doctor will probably tell you that you should not take ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone oral contraceptives.

If you experience any of the following symptoms while receiving ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment: shortness of breath, leg pain, sudden chest pain, sudden severe headache, sudden changes in vision, weakness or numbness in an arm or leg, or trouble speaking.

---

**Ethinyl Estradiol and Norethindrone (Oral Contraceptives)**

**How Should This Medicine Be Used?**

*   Ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone oral contraceptives come in tablets, chewable tablets, oral disintegrating tablets, or capsules to take by mouth.
*   Take once a day on the days specified by your doctor. Take your oral contraceptive at the same time on those days.
*   Chew the chewable tablets and swallow without water.
*   Place oral disintegrating tablets on the tongue and allow to disintegrate. Follow with 8 oz (240 mL) of water.

**Important Information**

*   Oral contraceptives come in many different brands. Different brands contain different doses and may also contain inactive tablets or ones containing iron.
*   Be sure that you know which brand of oral contraceptives you are using and exactly how you should use it. Ask your doctor or pharmacist for a copy of the manufacturer's information for the patient and read it carefully.

**Starting Your Oral Contraceptive**

*   Your doctor will tell you when you should start taking your oral contraceptive. It is usually started on the first day of your menstrual period or on the first Sunday after bleeding begins.
*   You will probably be told to use another method of birth control during the first 7 days that you take your oral contraceptive. Talk to your doctor or pharmacist about what method is best for you.

**Experiencing Withdrawal Bleeding**

*   You will probably experience withdrawal bleeding similar to a menstrual period while you are taking the inactive tablets or during the time that you do not take your oral contraceptive.
*   If you are taking the type of packet that only contains active tablets, you will not experience any scheduled bleeding, but you may experience unexpected bleeding and spotting, especially at the beginning of your treatment.

**Vomiting or Diarrhea**

*   If you vomit or have diarrhea while you are taking ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone oral contraceptive, it may not work as well. If this happens, contact your doctor about what to do.
*   You may be told to use a back-up method for 7 days. Talk to your doctor about an appropriate backup method of birth control in case it is needed at any point during therapy.

**Other Uses for This Medicine**

*   Oral contraceptives are also sometimes used to treat heavy or irregular menstruation and endometriosis (a condition in which the type of tissue that lines the uterus [womb] grows in other areas of the body and causes pain, heavy or irregular menstruation [periods], and other symptoms).
*   Some oral contraceptives are also used to treat acne. Oral contraceptives treat acne by decreasing the amounts of certain natural substances that can cause acne.

**Precautions**

*   Do not stop taking oral contraceptives without talking to your doctor.
*   Continue to take them as directed even if you are spotting or bleeding, have an upset stomach, or do not think that you are likely to become pregnant.

**Ethinyl Estradiol and Norethindrone (Oral Contraceptives)**

\n\n

**How is this medication used?**

This medication is used to prevent pregnancy in women of childbearing age. It is also used to treat acne, heavy or irregular menstruation, and endometriosis.

\n\n

**What should I know before taking this medication?**

*   You should not take ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone oral contraceptives if you have a history of blood clots, stroke, or heart disease.
*   You should also avoid taking this medication if you have liver cancer, liver tumors, or other types of liver disease.
*   If you are overweight, your doctor may advise against taking this medication due to the increased risk of blood clots and other complications.

\n\n

**What special precautions should I follow?**

Before starting ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone oral contraceptives:

*   Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this drug, any part of this drug, or any other drugs, foods or substances.
*   Discuss any medications you are currently taking or plan to take before starting ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone oral contraceptives with your doctor and pharmacist.
*   Be aware that some medications may decrease the effectiveness of oral contraceptives (birth control pills). You will need to use another method of contraception to prevent pregnancy while taking these drugs together.

\n\n

**What special precautions should I follow?**

Before starting ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone oral contraceptives:

*   Tell your doctor if you have or have ever had diabetes that has affected your circulation; migraines or headaches that come along with other symptoms such as vision changes, weakness, and dizziness; high blood pressure that medication cannot control; breast cancer; liver cancer, liver tumors, or other types of liver disease; or unexplained vaginal bleeding.
*   Tell your doctor if you are overweight, and if you have or have ever had high blood cholesterol or fats; diabetes; depression; gallbladder disease; swelling in a part of your body.

\n\n

**What special precautions should I follow?**

Before starting ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone oral contraceptives:

*   Tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. If you miss periods while you are taking ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone oral contraceptives, you may be pregnant.
*   Call your doctor and have a pregnancy test if you experience symptoms of pregnancy such as nausea, vomiting, and breast tenderness, or if you suspect you may be pregnant.

\n\n

**What special precautions should I follow?**

Before starting ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone oral contraceptives:

*   If you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone oral contraceptives.

\n\n

**What special precautions should I follow?**

While taking ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone oral contraceptives:

*   You should know that oral contraceptives may cause dark skin patches, especially on the face. If you have experienced changes in your skin color during pregnancy or while you were taking oral contraceptives in the past, you should avoid exposure to real or artificial sunlight while you are taking oral contraceptives.
*   Wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen.

\n\n

**What special precautions should I follow?**

While taking ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone oral contraceptives:

*   Tell your doctor and pharmacist if you wear contact lenses. If you notice changes in vision or ability to wear your lenses while taking oral contraceptives, see an eye doctor.

\n\n

**What special dietary instructions should I follow?**

There are no specific dietary instructions for ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone oral contraceptives.

---

**Ethinyl Estradiol and Norethindrone (Oral Contraceptives)**

**Important Information for Contact Lens Wearers**

If you wear contact lenses, be aware that oral contraceptives may cause changes in vision or affect your ability to wear them. Consult an eye doctor if you notice any issues.

**Dietary Instructions**

Unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue with your normal diet.

**Missing a Dose**

If you miss doses of your oral contraceptive, you may not be protected from pregnancy. You might need to use a backup method of birth control for 7 days or until the end of the cycle. Check the manufacturer's instructions for specific guidance on missing doses. If you have questions, consult your doctor or pharmacist.

**Side Effects**

Oral contraceptives can cause side effects. Inform your doctor if any symptoms are severe or persist:

* Headache
* Nausea, vomiting
* Weight gain
* Acne
* Bleeding or spotting between menstrual periods
* Changes in menstrual flow
* Breast tenderness, enlargement, or discharge
* Swelling, redness, irritation, burning, or itching of the vagina
* Trouble sleeping, tiredness, loss of energy, or other mood change

Some side effects can be serious. If you experience symptoms listed in the IMPORTANT WARNING section or those mentioned above, stop taking ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone oral contraceptives and contact your doctor immediately or seek emergency medical treatment.

**Serious Side Effects**

* Yellowing of the skin or eyes
* Loss of appetite
* Extreme tiredness, weakness, or lack of energy
* Dark-colored urine
* Light-colored stool
* Pain or tenderness in the abdomen
* A lump in your breast
* Unusual bleeding, including menstrual bleeding that is unusually heavy or lasts for longer than 7 days in a row

Ethinyl estradiol and norethindrone oral contraceptives may increase the chance of developing liver tumors, which are not cancer but can cause serious bleeding. They may also increase the risk of breast or liver cancer. Discuss the risks with your doctor.

**Storage and Disposal**

Keep this medication in its original packet, tightly closed, and out of reach of children. Store it at room temperature, away from excess heat and moisture (not in the bathroom). Dispose of unneeded medications through a medicine take-back program or by consulting your pharmacist about safe disposal methods. Do not flush this medication down the toilet. Visit the FDA's Safe Disposal of Medicines website for more information.

---

**Ethinyl Estradiol and Norethindrone (Oral Contraceptives)**

**Storage and Disposal**

Keep this medication in the packet it came in, tightly closed, and out of reach of children. Store it at room temperature and away from excess heat and moisture (not in the bathroom).

Dispose of unneeded medications in a way so that pets, children, and other people cannot take them. Do not flush this medication down the toilet. Use a medicine take-back program. Talk to your pharmacist about take-back programs in your community.

**In Case of Emergency/Overdose**

In case of overdose, call the poison control helpline at 1-800-222-1222. Information is also available online at https://www.poisonhelp.org/help. If the victim has collapsed, had a seizure, has trouble breathing, or can't be awakened, immediately call emergency services at 911.

Symptoms of overdose may include:

* nausea
* vaginal bleeding

**What Other Information Should I Know?**

Keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. You should have a complete physical examination every year, including blood pressure measurements, breast and pelvic exams, and a Pap test. Follow your doctor's directions for examining your breasts; report any lumps immediately.

Before you have any laboratory tests, tell the laboratory personnel that you take oral contraceptives.

Do not let anyone else take your medication. Ask your pharmacist any questions you have about refilling your prescription.

Keep a written list of all of the prescription and nonprescription (over-the-counter) medicines, vitamins, minerals, and dietary supplements you are taking. Bring this list with you each time you visit a doctor or if you are admitted to the hospital.

**Ethinyl Estradiol and Norgestimate (Oral Contraceptives)**

**Why is this medication prescribed?**

Oral contraceptives (birth-control pills) containing ethinyl estradiol (an estrogen) and norgestimate (a progestin) are used to prevent pregnancy. Estrogen and progestin are two female sex hormones. Combinations of estrogen and progestin work by preventing ovulation (the release of eggs from the ovaries).

Oral contraceptives are an effective method of birth control, but they do not prevent the spread of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV, the virus that causes acquired immunodeficiency syndrome [AIDS]) and other sexually transmitted diseases.

**How should this medicine be used?**

Ethinyl estradiol and norgestimate oral contraceptives come as tablets to take by mouth. Take once a day on the days specified by your doctor. Take your oral contraceptive at around the same time on those days.

Take ethinyl estradiol and norgestimate oral contraceptives exactly as directed. Do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed by your doctor.

Ethinyl estradiol and norgestimate oral contraceptives come in many different brands. Different brands of oral contraceptives contain different doses and may also contain inactive tablets or ones containing iron. Oral contraceptives are taken on specific schedules. Be sure that you know which brand of oral contraceptives you are using and exactly how you should use it. Ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer's information for the patient and read it carefully.

Your doctor will tell you when you should start taking your oral contraceptive. It is usually started on the first day of your menstrual period or on the first Sunday after bleeding begins. You will probably be told to use another method of birth control during the first 7 days that you take your oral contraceptive. Talk to your doctor or pharmacist about what method is best for you. Follow these directions carefully to prevent pregnancy.

You will probably experience withdrawal bleeding similar to a menstrual period while you are taking the inactive tablets or during the time that you do not take your oral contraceptive. If you are taking the type of packet that only contains active tablets, you will not experience any scheduled bleeding, but you may experience unexpected bleeding and spotting, especially at the beginning of your treatment. Be sure to start taking your new packet on schedule even if you are still bleeding.

If you vomit or have diarrhea while you are taking ethinyl estradiol and norgestimate oral contraceptives, it may not work as well. If this happens, contact your doctor about what to do. You may be told to use a back-up method for 7 days. Talk to your doctor about an appropriate backup method of birth control in case it is needed at any point during therapy.

**What special precautions should I follow?**

Ethinyl estradiol and norgestimate oral contraceptives may cause heart attacks, blood clots, and strokes. Tell your doctor if you smoke cigarettes or are over 35 years of age or if you have or have ever had blood clots in your legs, lungs, or eyes; conditions in which the blood clots easily; coronary artery disease (clogged blood vessels leading to the heart); cerebrovascular disease (clogging or weakening of the blood vessels within the brain or leading to the brain); a stroke or mini-stroke; an irregular heartbeat; heart or heart valve disease; a heart attack; or chest pain. Your doctor will probably tell you that you should not take ethinyl estradiol and norgestimate oral contraceptives.

If you experience any of the following symptoms while receiving ethinyl estradiol and norgestimate, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment: shortness of breath, leg pain, sudden chest pain, sudden severe headache, sudden changes in vision, weakness or numbness in an arm or leg, trouble speaking.

**What should I do if I forget a dose?**

If you miss a dose of ethinyl estradiol and norgestimate oral contraceptives, take it as soon as you remember. If you are taking the type of packet that only contains active tablets, you may experience unexpected bleeding and spotting, especially at the beginning of your treatment. Be sure to start taking your new packet on schedule even if you are still bleeding.

**What side effects can this medication cause?**

Ethinyl estradiol and norgestimate oral contraceptives may cause heart attacks, blood clots, and strokes. Tell your doctor if you smoke cigarettes or are over 35 years of age or if you have or have ever had blood clots in your legs, lungs, or eyes; conditions in which the blood clots easily; coronary artery disease (clogged blood vessels leading to the heart); cerebrovascular disease (clogging or weakening of the blood vessels within the brain or leading to the brain); a stroke or mini-stroke; an irregular heartbeat; heart or heart valve disease; a heart attack; or chest pain. Your doctor will probably tell you that you should not take ethinyl estradiol and norgestimate oral contraceptives.

If you experience any of the following symptoms while receiving ethinyl estradiol and norgestimate, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment: shortness of breath, leg pain, sudden chest pain, sudden severe headache, sudden changes in vision, weakness or numbness in an arm or leg, trouble speaking.

**What should I know about storage and disposal of this medication?**

Store ethinyl estradiol and norgestimate oral contraceptives at room temperature, away from moisture and heat. Do not store them in the bathroom or near a window. Keep them out of reach of children and pets.

Dispose of unused ethinyl estradiol and norgestimate oral contraceptives properly. Do not flush them down the toilet or drain. Instead, take them to a community collection program or a pharmacy that participates in a take-back program.

**In case of emergency/overdose**

If you experience any of the following symptoms while receiving ethinyl estradiol and norgestimate, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment: shortness of breath, leg pain, sudden chest pain, sudden severe headache, sudden changes in vision, weakness or numbness in an arm or leg, trouble speaking.

**What other information should I know?**

Ethinyl estradiol and norgestimate oral contraceptives come in many different brands. Different brands of oral contraceptives contain different doses and may also contain inactive tablets or ones containing iron. Oral contraceptives are taken on specific schedules. Be sure that you know which brand of oral contraceptives you are using and exactly how you should use it. Ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer's information for the patient and read it carefully.

You will probably be told to use another method of birth control during the first 7 days that you take your oral contraceptive. Talk to your doctor or pharmacist about what method is best for you. Follow these directions carefully to prevent pregnancy.

You will probably experience withdrawal bleeding similar to a menstrual period while you are taking the inactive tablets or during the time that you do not take your oral contraceptive. If you are taking the type of packet that only contains active tablets, you will not experience any scheduled bleeding, but you may experience unexpected bleeding and spotting, especially at the beginning of your treatment. **Ethinyl Estradiol and Norgestimate (Oral Contraceptives)**

**Important Information**

* If you wear contact lenses, be aware that changes in vision or ability to wear your lenses may occur while taking oral contraceptives. Consult an eye doctor if you notice any changes.

**Dietary Instructions**

Unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet.

**Missing a Dose**

If you miss doses of your oral contraceptive, you may not be protected from pregnancy. You may need to use a backup method of birth control for 7 days or until the end of the cycle. Every brand of oral contraceptives comes with specific directions to follow if you miss one or more doses. Carefully read the directions in the manufacturer's information for the patient that came with your oral contraceptive when you first start taking it. If you have any questions, call your doctor or pharmacist.

**Side Effects**

Ethinyl estradiol and norgestimate oral contraceptives may cause side effects. Tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away:

* Headache
* Nausea, vomiting
* Weight gain
* Spotting or irregular bleeding between periods
* Swelling, redness, irritation, burning, or itching of the vagina
* Breast tenderness, enlargement, or discharge
* Swelling of the hands, arms, feet, and leg
* Difficulty in sleeping, weakness, lack of energy, fatigue, or change in mood

Some side effects can be serious. If you experience any of these symptoms or those listed in the IMPORTANT WARNING section, stop taking ethinyl estradiol and norgestimate and call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment:

* Yellowing of the skin or eyes
* Pain or tenderness in the abdomen
* A lump in your breast
* Unusual bleeding, including menstrual bleeding that is unusually heavy or that lasts for longer than 7 days in a row

Oral contraceptives may increase the chance that you will develop liver tumors. These tumors are not a form of cancer, but they can break and cause serious bleeding inside the body. Oral contraceptives may also increase the chance that you will develop breast or liver cancer. Talk to your doctor about the risks of using oral contraceptives.

**Storage and Disposal**

title: Ethinyl Estradiol and Norgestrel (Oral Contraceptives): MedlinePlus Drug Information
content:
**Ethinyl Estradiol and Norgestrel (Oral Contraceptives)**

**Why is this medication prescribed?**

Oral contraceptives (birth-control pills) containing ethinyl estradiol (an estrogen) and norgestrel (a progestin) are used to prevent pregnancy. Estrogen and progestin are two female sex hormones. Combinations of estrogen and progestin work by preventing ovulation (the release of eggs from the ovaries).

Oral contraceptives are an effective method of birth control, but they do not prevent the spread of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV, the virus that causes acquired immunodeficiency syndrome [AIDS]) and other sexually transmitted diseases.

**How should this medicine be used?**

Ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel oral contraceptives come as tablets to take by mouth. Take once a day on the days specified by your doctor. Take your oral contraceptive at around the same time on those days.

Take ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel oral contraceptives exactly as directed. Do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed by your doctor.

Oral contraceptives come in many different brands. Different brands of oral contraceptives contain different doses and may also contain inactive tablets or ones containing iron. Oral contraceptives are taken on specific schedules. Be sure that you know which brand of oral contraceptives you are using and exactly how you should use it. Ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer's information for the patient and read it carefully.

Your doctor will tell you when you should start taking your oral contraceptive. It is usually started on the first day of your menstrual period or on the first Sunday after bleeding begins. You will probably be told to use another method of birth control during the first 7 days that you take your oral contraceptive. Talk to your doctor or pharmacist about what method is best for you. Follow these directions carefully to prevent pregnancy.

You will probably experience withdrawal bleeding similar to a menstrual period while you are taking the inactive tablets or during the time that you do not take your oral contraceptive. If you are taking the type of packet that only contains active tablets, you will not experience any scheduled bleeding, but you may experience unexpected bleeding and spotting, especially at the beginning of your treatment. Be sure to start taking your new packet on schedule even if you are still bleeding.

If you vomit or have diarrhea while you are taking ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel oral contraceptives, it may not work as well. If this happens, contact your doctor about what to do. You may be told to use a back-up method for 7 days. Talk to your doctor about an appropriate backup method of birth control in case it is needed at any point during therapy.

**What special precautions should I follow?**

Ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel oral contraceptives may cause heart attacks, blood clots, and strokes. Tell your doctor if you smoke cigarettes or are over 35 years of age or if you have or have ever had blood clots in your legs, lungs, or eyes; conditions in which the blood clots easily; coronary artery disease (clogged blood vessels leading to the heart); cerebrovascular disease (clogging or weakening of the blood vessels within the brain or leading to the brain); a stroke or mini-stroke; an irregular heartbeat; heart or heart valve disease; a heart attack; or chest pain. Your doctor will probably tell you that you should not take ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel oral contraceptives.

If you experience any of the following symptoms while receiving ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment: shortness of breath, leg pain, sudden chest pain, sudden severe headache, sudden changes in vision, weakness or numbness in an arm or leg, trouble speaking.

**What should I do if I forget a dose?**

If you vomit or have diarrhea while you are taking ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel oral contraceptives, it may not work as well. If this happens, contact your doctor about what to do. You may be told to use a back-up method for 7 days. Talk to your doctor about an appropriate backup method of birth control in case it is needed at any point during therapy.

**What side effects can this medication cause?**

Ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel oral contraceptives may cause heart attacks, blood clots, and strokes. Tell your doctor if you smoke cigarettes or are over 35 years of age or if you have or have ever had blood clots in your legs, lungs, or eyes; conditions in which the blood clots easily; coronary artery disease (clogged blood vessels leading to the heart); cerebrovascular disease (clogging or weakening of the blood vessels within the brain or leading to the brain); a stroke or mini-stroke; an irregular heartbeat; heart or heart valve disease; a heart attack; or chest pain. Your doctor will probably tell you that you should not take ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel oral contraceptives.

If you experience any of the following symptoms while receiving ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment: shortness of breath, leg pain, sudden chest pain, sudden severe headache, sudden changes in vision, weakness or numbness in an arm or leg, trouble speaking.

**What should I know about storage and disposal of this medication?**

Store ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel oral contraceptives at room temperature, away from moisture and heat. Do not store in the bathroom. Keep out of reach of children.

Dispose of unused ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel oral contraceptives properly. Do not flush them down the toilet or drain. Ask your pharmacist about disposal instructions.

**In case of emergency/overdose**

If you experience any of the following symptoms while receiving ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment: shortness of breath, leg pain, sudden chest pain, sudden severe headache, sudden changes in vision, weakness or numbness in an arm or leg, trouble speaking.

**What other information should I know?**

Oral contraceptives come in many different brands. Different brands of oral contraceptives contain different doses and may also contain inactive tablets or ones containing iron. Oral contraceptives are taken on specific schedules. Be sure that you know which brand of oral contraceptives you are using and exactly how you should use it. Your doctor will tell you when you should start taking your oral contraceptive. It is usually started on the first day of your menstrual period or on the first Sunday after bleeding begins. You will probably be told to use another method of birth control during the first 7 days that you take your oral contraceptive. Talk to your doctor or pharmacist about what method is best for you. Follow these directions carefully to prevent pregnancy.

You will probably experience withdrawal bleeding similar to a menstrual period while you are taking the inactive tablets or during the time that you do not take your oral contraceptive. If you are taking the type of packet that only contains active tablets, you will not experience any scheduled bleeding, but you may experience unexpected bleeding and spotting, especially at the beginning of your treatment. You may be told to use a back-up method for 7 days. Talk to your doctor about an appropriate backup method of birth control in case it is needed at any point during therapy.

**Other Uses for This Medicine**

*   Oral contraceptives are also sometimes used to treat heavy or irregular menstruation and endometriosis (a condition in which the type of tissue that lines the uterus [womb] grows in other areas of the body and causes pain, heavy or irregular menstruation [periods], and other symptoms).

**Ethinyl Estradiol and Norgestrel (Oral Contraceptives)**

**MedlinePlus Drug Information**

**Part 3/5**

**Uses**

*   To prevent pregnancy in women of childbearing age
*   To treat acne in certain patients by decreasing the amounts of certain natural substances that can cause acne
*   To treat heavy or irregular menstruation and endometriosis (a condition in which the type of tissue that lines the uterus [womb] grows in other areas of the body and causes pain, heavy or irregular menstruation [periods], and other symptoms)

**What special precautions should I follow?**

*   Before taking ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel oral contraceptives, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this drug, any part of this drug, or any other drugs, foods or substances. Tell your doctor or pharmacist about the allergy and what symptoms you had.
*   Some medications should not be taken with ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel oral contraceptives. Make sure you have discussed any medications you are currently taking or plan to take before starting ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel oral contraceptives with your doctor and pharmacist.
*   Before starting, stopping, or changing any medications while taking ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel oral contraceptives, please get the advice of your doctor or pharmacist.
*   Some medications may decrease the effectiveness of oral contraceptives (birth control pills). You will need to use another method of contraception to prevent pregnancy while taking these drugs. Talk to your doctor about other ways to prevent pregnancy while you are taking this medication
*   The following nonprescription or herbal product may interact with ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel oral contraceptives: St. John's wort. Be sure to let your doctor and pharmacist know that you are taking this medication before you start taking ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel oral contraceptives. Do not start this medication while taking ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel oral contraceptives without discussing with your healthcare provider.
*   Tell your doctor if you have or have ever had diabetes that has affected your circulation; migraines or headaches that come along with other symptoms such as vision changes, weakness, and dizziness; high blood pressure that medication cannot control; breast cancer; liver cancer, liver tumors, or other types of liver disease; or unexplained vaginal bleeding. Your doctor will probably tell you that you should not take ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel oral contraceptives.
*   Tell your doctor if you are overweight, and if you have or have ever had high blood cholesterol or fats; diabetes; depression; gallbladder disease; swelling in a part of your body.
*   If you miss periods while you are taking ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel oral contraceptives, you may be pregnant. Ask your doctor what you should do if you miss a period. Call your doctor and have a pregnancy test if you experience symptoms of pregnancy such as nausea, vomiting, and breast tenderness, or if you suspect you may be pregnant.

If you have experienced changes in your skin color during pregnancy or while you were taking oral contraceptives in the past, you should avoid exposure to real or artificial sunlight while you are taking oral contraceptives. Wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen.
*   Tell your doctor and pharmacist if you wear contact lenses. If you notice changes in vision or ability to wear your lenses while taking oral contraceptives, see an eye doctor.

None specified

If you wear contact lenses, be aware that changes in vision or ability to wear your lenses while taking oral contraceptives may occur. Consult an eye doctor if you notice any changes.

**Dietary Instructions**

Continue your normal diet unless your doctor advises otherwise.

**Missing a Dose**

If you miss doses of your oral contraceptive, you may not be protected from pregnancy. You may need to use a backup method of birth control for 7 days or until the end of the cycle. Refer to the manufacturer's instructions for specific directions on handling missed doses.

**Side Effects**

Ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel oral contraceptives may cause side effects, including:

* Headache
* Nausea, vomiting
* Weight gain
* Spotting or irregular bleeding between periods
* Swelling, redness, irritation, burning, or itching of the vagina

* Swelling of the hands, arms, feet, and leg

Some side effects can be serious. If you experience:

* Yellowing of the skin or eyes
* Pain or tenderness in the abdomen
* A lump in your breast
* Unusual bleeding, including menstrual bleeding that is unusually heavy or lasts for longer than 7 days in a row

Stop taking ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel oral contraceptives and consult your doctor immediately.

Oral contraceptives may increase the chance of developing liver tumors. These tumors are not cancerous but can cause serious bleeding inside the body.

Oral contraceptives may also increase the risk of breast or liver cancer. Discuss the risks with your doctor.

Keep this medication in its original container, tightly closed, and out of reach of children. Store it at room temperature and away from excess heat and moisture. Dispose of unneeded medications through a medicine take-back program or by consulting your pharmacist about safe disposal methods.

**Ethinyl Estradiol, Drospirenone, and Levomefolate (Oral Contraceptives)**

**Why is this medication prescribed?**

Oral contraceptives (birth-control pills) containing ethinyl estradiol (an estrogen), drospirenone (a progestin), and levomefolate (a B vitamin) are used to prevent pregnancy, treat certain types of acne, and to relieve the symptoms of premenstrual dysphoric disorder (symptoms that occur before the menstrual period each month). Levomefolate is used to increase amounts of iron in the body to reduce the risk of certain birth defects. Estrogen and progestin are two female sex hormones. Combinations of estrogen and progestin work by preventing ovulation (the release of eggs from the ovaries). Oral contraceptives treat acne by decreasing the amounts of certain natural substances in the body that can cause acne

Oral contraceptives are an effective method of birth control, but they do not prevent the spread of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV, the virus that causes acquired immunodeficiency syndrome [AIDS]) and other sexually transmitted diseases.

**How should this medicine be used?**

Ethinyl estradiol, drospirenone, and levomefolate oral contraceptives comes as a tablets to take by mouth. Take once a day on the days specified by your doctor. Take your oral contraceptive at the same time on those days.

Ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer's information for the patient and read it carefully.

Ethinyl estradiol, drospirenone, and levomefolate oral contraceptives may cause heart attacks, blood clots, and strokes.
